dt: {bc}in the part of your mind where thoughts and memories are kept
used to describe ideas, memories, etc., that someone has but that are not usually thought about or not perfectly remembered

dt.t: The thought of retiring and moving out into the country has been {it}in the back of her mind{/it} for many years.

dt: When {it}your back is to/against the wall{/it} or {it}you have your back to/against the wall{/it} you are in a bad position in which you are forced to do something in order to avoid failure.

dt.t: {it}With our backs to the wall{/it} we made a last desperate effort to finish on time.
We knew that with so little time left {it}we had our backs to the wall{/it}.

dt: {bc}with backs opposite or against each other

dt.t: The soldiers stood {it}back to back{/it}.
She won the annual competition two times {it}back to back{/it}. [={it}in a row{/it}]

dt: {bc}with the back where the front should be

dt.t: He accidentally put the sweater on {it}back to front{/it}. [={it}front to back, backwards{/it}]

dt: {bc}to get control of (something you are trying to stop or defeat) {bc}to greatly weaken or subdue (something)

dt: {bc}to become angry or annoyed and want to fight or argue

dt.t: He {it}gets his back up{/it} and becomes defensive whenever someone questions his work.

dt: {bc}in an area at the back of something

dt.t: There was only room for one passenger in front. The rest of us sat {it}in back{/it}. [={it}in the back{/it}]

dt: Someone who is always or frequently criticizing you or telling you what to do is {it}on your back{/it} and won't {phrase}get off your back{/phrase}.

dt.t: He says his wife is always {it}on his back{/it} about doing chores around the house.
{it}Get off my back{/it}! I'm working as hard as I can!
My boss is always criticizing me. I wish I knew some way to {it}get him off my back{/it}.

dt: If you are {it}(flat) on your back{/it} you are lying with your back against the ground, on a bed, etc.

dt.t: The accident left him (lying) {it}flat on his back{/it} (in bed) for two weeks.

dt: This phrase is sometimes used figuratively.

dt.t: The stock market has been {it}flat on its back{/it} [=has been doing very poorly] in recent weeks.

dt: {bc}in the area behind something (such as a building)

dt.t: In my youth we didn't have a toilet in the house but there was one {it}out back{/it}.

dt: {bc}to offend or annoy someone {bc}to make someone angry or ready to argue

dt.t: I don't want to question his decision because that will just {it}put his back up{/it}.

dt: {bc}to work very hard at (something) {bc}to put a lot of effort into (something)

dt.t: To clean that floor you'll have to {it}put your back into{/it} it.
You'll really have to {it}put your back into{/it} this project if you want it to succeed.

dt: In British English, to be {phrase}glad/happy (etc.) to see the back of{/phrase} someone is to be glad to see someone finally going away.

dt.t: He's done nothing but make trouble and I'll be {it}glad to see the back of{/it} him! [=I'll be glad when he has gone]

dt: {bc}to turn so that you are facing away from someone

dt.t: He {it}turned his back{/it} and walked away from me.

dt: {bc}to protect someone who is doing something that is dangerous or risky

dt.t: The police officer's partner always {it}watches his back{/it}.

dt: If people tell you to {it}watch your back{/it}, they are telling you to be careful.

dt.t: I hear the boss is in a bad mood this morning, so you'd better {it}watch your back{/it}.

def: {bc} the act of coming or going back to the place you started from or to a place where you were before
{bc} the act of going back to an activity, job, situation, etc. {bc} the act of starting to do something again after stopping
{bc} the fact that something (such as a condition, feeling, or situation) happens again

dt: {bc}the act of coming or going back to the place you started from or to a place where you were before

dt: {bc}the act of going back to an activity, job, situation, etc. {bc}the act of starting to do something again after stopping

a {it}return{/it} to the old ways of farming

dt: {bc}the fact that someone or something changes {it}to{/it} a condition or state that existed before

shortdef: the act of coming or going back to the place you started from or to a place where you were before
the act of going back to an activity, job, situation, etc. : the act of starting to do something again after stopping
